title: Is the expression 'one in the same' grammatically incorrect? - Quora

response.answer_text: You might construct a way in which you could use a phrase "one in the same" and it would be grammatical—as long as in makes sense with the antecedent of same.  For instance: Tara threw two pieces of fish food in the bowl on the left and Roger put one in the same, but Nancy put three into the one on the right. However, I assume your question is actually "which is the proper spelling of the common phrase?" and it's "one and the same". The President and the Commander-in-Chief are one and the same.

The common colloquial phrase in English is "one and the same." Often used this way: Speaker 1 "Hey, did you hear Reese got promoted to the supervisor's job?"Speaker 2 "Really? Isn't he the one who was so drunk at the office party?"Speaker 1 "One and the same." Can often be substituted for or replaced with "the very same." It's a slightly sarcastic affirmative response that something or someone is indeed exactly that which was being described.
It is "one and the same thing". Because the two things are as one thing and they are as the same thing. So they are both "one" and "the same".
The commonly used phrase you are probably looking for is "one and the same," though the phrase "one in the same" isn't grammatically incorrect, it would be valid in certain sentences.
Well, it depends on what context you are talking about , I can`t judge it by only a phrase.You can say, for example, one in the same class feels it is no necessary to attend class anymore.
No, this is not correct.I believe that you mean to say 'one and the same'.

Just to make it clear: of course it is grammatically correct - I personally can't think of a situation where one could use it. It's just not a fixed expression. Similar to how "without further ado" can't be replaced with "without further to do", even though both are grammatically compatible with the English language rules, you can't replace one fixed expression with a similar sounding one.
